title: Carbon Tax Effectiveness
summary: Examination of claims about carbon pricing policies and their effectiveness in reducing emissions and economic impacts.

claims.statement: Carbon taxes have reduced emissions in countries that implemented them

evidenceFor.point: British Columbia saw 5-15% reduction in fuel consumption after carbon tax implementation
Sweden's carbon tax contributed to 25% emissions reduction since 1990
Meta-analysis of 37 carbon pricing schemes found average 2% annual emission reduction

evidenceAgainst.point: Emission reductions often coincided with other policies, making attribution difficult
Some industries relocated emissions rather than reducing them

claims.statement: Carbon taxes destroy jobs and harm the economy

evidenceFor.point: Some energy-intensive industries have seen job losses in regions with carbon pricing

evidenceAgainst.point: British Columbia's economy grew faster than the rest of Canada after implementing carbon tax
Revenue recycling (rebates/tax cuts) has offset consumer cost impacts
Clean energy sectors have created more jobs than lost in fossil fuel industries

claims.statement: A carbon tax of $50 per ton would raise gas prices by about $0.50 per gallon

evidenceFor.point: CO2 emissions from gasoline are approximately 8.89 kg per gallon, making the calculation accurate
Multiple economic analyses confirm this price relationship
